article.description: Juan Dixon scored a season-high 28 points off the bench and Martell Webster and Ruben Patterson made key plays down the stretch in overtime as the Blazers halted a six-game skid with a thrilling 98-95 victory over the Hornets.
article.headline: Blazers snap skid, send Hornets to fourth straight loss
article.linkText: Blazers snap skid, send Hornets to fourth straight loss
article.story:
PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) -- The Portland Trail Blazers had played some dismal fourth quarters during a six-game losing streak. Some impressive play down the stretch Friday night helped them end that skid. Reserve Juan Dixon scored a season-high 28 points and rookie Martell Webster made a go-ahead 3-pointer in overtime, leading the Blazers over the New Orleans Hornets 98-95. Ruben Patterson added a fadeaway jumper with 10.5 seconds left for the Blazers, who set a season high in points to rebound from blowing a 14-point lead in a loss to Minnesota on Wednesday. "The other night we didn't get stops and we didn't knock down the open shots we got," Blazers coach Nate McMillan said. "Tonight we made the stops and knocked down the shots and that was the difference between winning and losing." The Hornets were just 1-of-6 in overtime and squandered opportunities with four turnovers in the fourth quarter. "We can't come up with empty possessions like that in the fourth quarter, especially when we have the lead," said Hornets guard Speedy Claxton, whose 27 points were one off his career high. Chris Paul had 21 points, 10 assists and seven rebounds for the Hornets, whose four-game losing streak is their longest of the season. David West added 12 points. New Orleans had a two-point advantage when the 19-year-old Webster made a wide-open 3 from the corner to make give Portland a 94-93 edge. Patterson's shot extended the lead and Steve Blake hit two key free throws for the Blazers. Paul made a meaningless jumper for the Hornets at the buzzer. Viktor Khryapa had 16 points and Joel Przybilla had 11 points and 19 rebounds for Portland. Patterson added 12 points. The Blazers had led in the fourth quarter during three of their last five games but lost all of them because of their sloppy play. Portland got another subpar game from Zach Randolph, who had just nine points and two rebounds after being held out of the starting lineup for arriving late to the morning shootaround. Randolph, averaging 17.8 points and 8.9 rebounds, angered McMillan with poor shot selection in the Minnesota game. Randolph was replaced in the starting lineup by Patterson, while Khryapa got his second start in the place of leading scorer Darius Miles, who has missed four games and decided Thursday to have surgery on his ailing knee on Dec. 16. There were 20 lead changes and nine ties in the game, but New Orleans, led by Claxton's 17 first-half points, was ahead for much of the first three quarters. Dixon had 13 points in the fourth quarter, making all six of his shots. "The boy hit some shots for us, big shots," Patterson said. "I give him all the credit tonight." Claxton made seven of his first eight shots, and the Hornets led by as many as seven points in the first half. Paul hit back-to-back jumpers to give New Orleans a 46-39 lead just before halftime, but Sebastian Telfair beat the buzzer with a fadeaway 12-footer. The Blazers tied it at 72 on Dixon's 22-footer in the fourth quarter. New Orleans went on a 6-0 run, with Claxton scoring twice, but Portland responded with an 11-0 run that Patterson capped with a breakaway dunk to make it 85-82 with just over 3 minutes to play. Paul hit an off-balance lean-in jumper to give the New Orleans the lead, but Dixon's jumper sent it to overtime tied at 89.

Game notes
Portland was without center Theo Ratliff, who sat out for the fifth time this season with a sore left foot. ... A sore knee kept Randolph out of practice Thursday. ... New Orleans had won four of the last five in the series, which Portland leads 25-12. ... The Blazers shot just 48 percent (12-of-25) from the foul line.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
